scenarioDescription:
The GJ 849 Exoplanetary System


Overview

GJ 849 is a star with 0.49 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.47 times its radius. It is located 28.70 light years away from the solar system and is estimated to be 3 billion years old, as compared to the Sun which is roughly 4.6 billion years old.

GJ 849 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.


Exoplanets in the GJ 849 system


GJ 849 b

GJ 849 b was discovered by the W. M. Keck Observatory observatory, in 2006-12, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 2.41 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 849 b is 286.200 times the mass of Earth. The radius of GJ 849 b is 13.900 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, GJ 849 b is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.


GJ 849 c

GJ 849 c was discovered by the W. M. Keck Observatory observatory, in 2014-01, using the radial velocity method. Its semi-major axis is 4.97 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. The mass of GJ 849 c is 223.236 times the mass of Earth. The radius of GJ 849 c is 14.000 that of Earth. At more than 50 Earth masses, GJ 849 c is a gas giant, a planet whose mass is mostly made up of hydrogen and helium, like Jupiter and Saturn in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanetary system GJ 849, which contains 2 exoplanets and was discovered by the W. M. Keck Observatory.
name: GJ 849 - System With 2 Exoplanets
